docs.lead_paragraph: A doctor who stabbed a pregnant nurse in the Bronx with a syringe that contained an abortion-inducing drug was sentenced yesterday to two years in state prison for the attack, the authorities said. The doctor, Stephen Pack, 45, who lived in Chappaqua, N.Y., pleaded guilty to assault and abortion charges in January. If the case had gone to trial, he could have faced up to seven years in prison for trying to terminate the pregnancy of Joy Schepis, a nurse who had worked with him at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

headline.main: Doctor From Bronx Hospital Is Sentenced in Needle Attack

docs.abstract: Dr Stephen Pack is sentenced to two years in prison for trying inject Joy Schepis, nurse he worked with at Montefiore Hospital in Bronx, with syringe containing drug to induce abortion (M)
docs.snippet: A doctor who stabbed a pregnant nurse in the Bronx with a syringe that contained an abortion-inducing drug was sentenced yesterday to two years in state prison for the attack, the authorities said.    The doctor, Stephen Pack, 45, who lived in...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was billed as a ''Surgeon General's Call to Action.'' In the waning months of the Clinton administration, Surgeon General David Satcher laid the groundwork for a far-reaching report on sexual attitudes and education. The paper appeared set to showcase the tolls of sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies on the young and urge comprehensive sex education in every grade, along with measures that would ''promote responsible sexual behavior'' like improved access to contraception.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''New Attention for the Idea That Abortion Averts Crime'' (Arts & Ideas pages, April 14) understates the possibility that good research could tell us more about the connection between abortion and crime.
docs.abstract: Dr Kenneth D Rosenberg letter on research on statistical connection between abortion and crime; says core issue is unintended pregnancies
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''New Attention for the Idea That Abortion Averts Crime'' (Arts & Ideas pages, April 14) understates the possibility that good research could tell us more about the connection between abortion and crime.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal investigators called today for much more stringent regulation of dietary supplements, saying current standards and their enforcement were grossly inadequate and allowed safety problems to go unchecked. In the final draft of a new report, the acting inspector general of the Health and Human Services Department said manufacturers of dietary supplements, the supplements themselves and their ingredients should be registered with the government.

headline.main: Tighter Rules Are Sought For Dietary Supplements

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Dept calls for much more stringent regulation of dietary supplements, saying current standards and their enforcement are grossly inadequate and allow safety problems to go unchecked; acting inspector general, Michael F Mangano, says in final draft of report that manufacturers of dietary supplements, supplements themselves and their ingredients should be registered with government (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn woman in her ninth month of pregnancy delivered a healthy baby yesterday after being stabbed three times by the mother of her boyfriend's two children, the police said. The victim, Nadine Ormsby, 27, was stabbed in the abdomen, chest and left forearm, the police said. Doctors at Kings County Hospital Center delivered her baby, a boy, by Caesarean section, said Sgt. Kim Royster, a police spokeswoman.

headline.main: Stabbing Victim Gives Birth To Healthy Baby by Caesarean

docs.abstract: Nadine Ormsby, Brooklyn woman in her ninth month of pregnancy, delivers healthy baby after being stabbed three times by Charisse Robinson, mother of her boyfriend's two children; police are trying to persuade Robinson to surrender but no charges have been filed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a mother who gained over 50 pounds with each of two pregnancies, I was not surprised to read ''Extra Pounds Can Jeopardize Nursing'' (April 10). Each time, I had difficulty establishing nursing, but ultimately succeeded.
docs.abstract: Sandra Rosenbaum letter on importance of hospitals having staff expertise to help new mothers establish nursing with their infants, noting difficulties of this for large-breasted and heavier women
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    As a mother who gained over 50 pounds with each of two pregnancies, I was not surprised to read ''Extra Pounds Can Jeopardize Nursing'' (April 10).    Each time, I had difficulty establishing nursing, but ultimately succeeded.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sixteen months after she suffered a miscarriage, Crown Princess Masako is again pregnant, Japan's imperial family announced today. The news, which came in an unusual late morning statement from the Imperial Household Agency, seemed deliberately couched in ambiguity, perhaps out of caution after the recent loss of a child.

headline.main: Japan's Imperial Family Reports Princess Masako Expecting Child

docs.abstract: Japan's imperial family announces that Crown Princess Masako is pregnant; news generates excitement in Japan, where there has been worried speculation since 37-year-old princess's miscarriage 16 months ago that immediate heirs to so-called Chrysanthemum Throne would be unable to produce eventual successor (M)
docs.snippet: Sixteen months after she suffered a miscarriage, Crown Princess Masako is again pregnant, Japan's imperial family announced today.    The news, which came in an unusual late morning statement from the Imperial Household Agency, seemed deliberately...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Victorian homes near Irving Avenue still retain the clapboard elegance they had when European immigrants helped to build this Westchester County suburb. The village officials are all white, still, and their concerns seem little changed from the days when diversity meant Irish, Jewish or Italian. But behind many of those Victorian porches are honeycombed apartments, each housing two or three Hispanic families. And though these Hispanic residents express great concern about the village's lack of low-income housing and health care for the poor, Port Chester officials rarely cite these as top priorities.

headline.main: Hispanic Influx Slowly Altering A Town Veneer

docs.abstract: Port Chester, NY, is glaring example of fact that Hispanics, while increasingly influential in numbers, are practically invisible in many areas of public and political life, particularly in Northeast; 2000 census shows that Port Chester is only Westchester community with plurality of Hispanic residents; village officials, who are all white, rarely cite as top priorities matters of great concern to Hispanic constituents: village's lack of low-income housing and health care for poor; many white residents of Port Chester echo sentiment of new mayor, Gerald L Logan, who says Port Chester needs to accommodate, but not pampr, its newest immigrants; photos; map, chart (M)
